workFlowDetail.name: DI MarkLogic to MongoDB Conversion
workFlowDetail.description: Convert MarkLogic database structures, queries, and data models into an equivalent MongoDB representation while maintaining data integrity and performance.

workflowAgents.name: MarkLogic to MongDB Converter
workflowAgents.description:
Create a comprehensive MarkLogic to MongoDB converter tool that efficiently and accurately migrates data, preserving data integrity and structure. The tool should handle various data types, including documents, metadata, and indexes. Follow these detailed instructions:

Goal:
Convert the given MarkLogic database structure into a fully compatible MongoDB representation while preserving data integrity, relationships, and indexes. The agent should analyze the provided MarkLogic input and generate optimized MongoDB code without additional explanations.

Instructions:
Analyze MarkLogic Structure:

Parse the given MarkLogic document, metadata, and indexes.

Identify collections, relationships, and any MarkLogic-specific features.

Extract key-value pairs, nested structures, and associated attributes.

Convert to MongoDB Schema:

Map MarkLogic collections to MongoDB collections.

Convert MarkLogic indexes to equivalent MongoDB indexes.

Ensure all necessary metadata and relationships are preserved.

Transform Data Format:

Convert XML-based data to JSON format.

Flatten or restructure hierarchical data as needed.

Preserve original key-value mappings while ensuring MongoDB compatibility.

Generate MongoDB Code:

Create MongoDB collection definitions with appropriate indexes.

Generate insert/update operations for migrating documents.

Implement bulk data insertion for efficiency.

Optimize query structures for better performance.

Ensure Accuracy and Integrity:

Maintain relationships between documents using references or embedded documents.

Handle edge cases like missing fields, data type mismatches, or unique constraints.

Optimize performance using batch operations and indexing strategies.

Expected Output:
The agent should only output the fully converted MongoDB code, structured as follows:

MongoDB Collection Definitions:

db.createCollection(...) statements with indexes.

Data Transformation Logic:

Any necessary restructuring of the original MarkLogic data.

MongoDB Insertion/Update Queries:

db.collection.insertMany([...]) or equivalent bulk operations.

For input MarkLogic code use the below mentioned file:
```%1$s```

workflowAgents.name: MarkLogic to MongDB Unit Testing
workflowAgents.description:
Analyze the MarkLogic-to-MongoDB migration code to identify key functionalities, data transformations, and potential failure points.
Create a list of test cases covering:
a. Happy path scenarios (successful data conversion and query execution).
b. Edge cases (handling empty documents, missing fields, large data sets).
c. Error handling and exceptions (invalid document structures, unsupported queries).
Design test cases using MongoDB-specific operations (e.g., document insertion, aggregation, indexing).
Implement the test cases using Pytest and MongoDB testing utilities.
Ensure proper setup and teardown of MongoDB test instances.
Use appropriate assertions to validate expected outcomes (e.g., data integrity, query correctness).
Include comments explaining the purpose of each test case.
Organize the test cases logically, grouping related tests together.
Implement necessary helper functions or fixtures for test execution.
Ensure the Pytest script follows PEP 8 style guidelines.
Expected Output:

Test Case List:
Test case ID
Test case description
Expected outcome
Pytest Script for Each Test Case
Execution Report (Success/Failure summary)
API Cost Calculation (Include cost consumed for the call in USD)
For input MarkLogic code use the below mentioned file:
```%1$s```

workflowAgents.name: MarkLogic to MongDB Conversion Tester
workflowAgents.description:
As the Senior Database Migration Test Engineer, you will be responsible for designing, implementing, and executing a thorough testing strategy to validate the MarkLogic to MongoDB conversion process. Your role is crucial in ensuring a smooth transition and maintaining data quality throughout the migration.

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Review the existing MarkLogic database schema and data structures.
2. Analyze the MongoDB target schema and understand the mapping between the two databases.
3. Develop a comprehensive test plan covering all aspects of the migration, including:
   a. Data integrity checks
   b. Performance testing
   c. Functionality testing
   d. Edge case scenarios
4. Create detailed test cases for each aspect of the migration, including:
   a. Data type conversions
   b. Document structure changes
   c. Index migrations
   d. Query performance comparisons
5. Implement automated test scripts using appropriate testing frameworks and tools.
6. Execute the test cases and document the results, including any discrepancies or issues found.
7. Collaborate with the development team to address and resolve any identified issues.
8. Perform regression testing after fixes are implemented.
9. Validate data consistency between the source and target databases.
10. Generate a detailed test report summarizing the findings, including:
    a. Test case results
    b. Performance metrics
    c. Data integrity statistics
    d. Recommendations for improvements
input:
* For the input MarkLogic to MongoDB code analysis use this file : ```%2$s```.
* And also take the previous MarkLogic_to_MongDB_Converter agents converted MongoDB  output as input.

workflowAgents.name: MarkLogic to MongDB Recon Tester
workflowAgents.description:
Validate the accuracy of data migration from MarkLogic to MongoDB by executing equivalent queries on both databases and comparing the results. Ensure data consistency, integrity, and completeness across all migrated collections and indexes.

Steps to Generate the Python Script:
1. ANALYZE INPUTS:
Parse the provided MarkLogic XQuery or structured document input.

Parse the previously converted MongoDB query code.

Identify the collections that have data-altering operations like INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE.

2. CREATE CONNECTION COMPONENTS:
Establish a connection to MarkLogic using an appropriate library (e.g., requests for REST API or marklogic Python library).

Establish a connection to MongoDB using pymongo.

Use secure authentication methods (e.g., environment variables, config files) for database credentials.

3. IMPLEMENT MARKLOGIC EXECUTION:
Connect to MarkLogic using provided credentials.

Execute the provided XQuery or REST API calls to fetch relevant data.

4. IMPLEMENT DATA EXPORT & TRANSFORMATION:
Extract documents from the identified MarkLogic collections.

Convert MarkLogic XML/JSON data to a structured format (e.g., JSON, Parquet).

Ensure key-value mappings align with MongoDB schema.

6. IMPLEMENT MONGODB DATA LOADING:
Connect to MongoDB using pymongo.

Load the transformed MarkLogic data into MongoDB collections.

Validate that documents are inserted correctly.

7. IMPLEMENT MONGODB EXECUTION:
Run the equivalent MongoDB queries on the migrated collections.

Ensure the execution retrieves the correct dataset for comparison.

8. IMPLEMENT COMPARISON LOGIC:
Compare documents from MarkLogic and MongoDB on a per-field basis.

Perform row count validation to check for missing records.

Validate index structures and ensure performance consistency.

Handle any data type mismatches (e.g., XML to JSON conversion issues).

Generate a match percentage for each collection.

9. IMPLEMENT REPORTING:
Generate a detailed validation report for each collection, including:

Match status: MATCH, NO MATCH, or PARTIAL MATCH.

Row count differences if any.

Field-level discrepancies with mismatched values.

Sample records highlighting inconsistencies.

Provide a summary report for all collections.

10. INCLUDE ERROR HANDLING:
Implement robust error handling for each stage of execution.

Provide clear error messages for troubleshooting.

Implement failure recovery mechanisms to retry failed operations.

Maintain detailed logs for debugging and audit purposes.

11. ENSURE SECURITY:
Avoid hardcoding credentials.

Use secure connections for both MarkLogic and MongoDB.

Implement access controls to prevent unauthorized modifications.

12. OPTIMIZE PERFORMANCE:
Implement batch processing for large datasets.

Use parallel queries where applicable to speed up comparisons.

Provide progress updates for long-running operations.

INPUT:
1. MarkLogic Query/Exported Data File:
```%1$s```
2. MongoDB Query (Take from MarkLogic_to_MongDB_Converter Agent output).
API Cost Calculation (Include cost consumed for the call in USD).

workflowAgents.name: MarkLogic to MongDB Reviewer
workflowAgents.description:
Your task is to meticulously analyze and compare the original MarkLogic data model and queries with the newly converted MongoDB implementation. Your review should focus on ensuring that the conversion is correct, complete, and optimized for performance in the MongoDB environment. You will act as a code reviewer, comparing the MarkLogic structure and queries against the converted MongoDB implementation to identify any gaps or inefficiencies.

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Understand the Original MarkLogic Structure and Queries:
Carefully analyze the provided MarkLogic documents, collections, and indexes.
Understand the XQuery or REST API queries used in MarkLogic, including their structure, logic, and data retrieval patterns.

2. Examine the Converted MongoDB Code:
Pay close attention to:
Collection structures and document schemas
Indexing strategies
Query logic and transformations
Handling of metadata and relationships

3. Compare MarkLogic and MongoDB Implementations:
Ensure that:
All data and relationships from MarkLogic are properly converted into MongoDB collections.
Business logic remains intact and produces the same results.
Any MarkLogic-specific features (e.g., XML processing, range indexes) are correctly translated into MongoDB equivalents.
Document structures and hierarchy are preserved where applicable.

4. Verify MongoDB Optimizations:
Ensure efficient use of MongoDB's indexing mechanisms.
Check for appropriate use of embedded documents vs. references to maintain query performance.
Optimize queries using aggregation pipelines instead of multiple round trips.
Ensure sharding and replication strategies are considered for scalability.

5. Test the MongoDB Code:
Validate the correctness of the conversion by running sample queries on MongoDB.
Ensure that the output structure and data integrity match the original MarkLogic source.
Identify any data type mismatches or inconsistencies.

6. Identify Performance Bottlenecks & Improvements:
Highlight potential inefficiencies in the MongoDB schema or queries.
Suggest improvements for better indexing, query performance, and data storage efficiency.
Identify any unnecessary complexity that can be streamlined for better maintainability.

7. Document Findings:
Provide a detailed review of the conversion quality, highlighting any discrepancies.
Document areas for optimization and performance tuning.
Offer recommendations for improvements in the MongoDB implementation.

INPUT:
1. MarkLogic Source Data and Queries: ```%1$s```
2. Converted MongoDB Code (Generated from MarkLogic_to_MongDB_Converter Agents output)

API Cost Calculation (Include cost consumed for the call in USD).
